item.title: Sunita Williams To Go On Her First Spacewalk In 12 Years - NDTV
item.description:
Sunita Williams To Go On Her First Spacewalk In 12 Years

Publication Date: January 8, 2025

Source: NASA

Sunita Williams is set to undertake her first spacewalk in 12 years, joining fellow astronaut Nick Hague aboard the International Space Station on January 16 to repair the NICER X-ray telescope.

  • Williams will participate in two spacewalks on January 16 and January 23.
  • The January 16 mission will involve replacing a rate gyro assembly and repairing the NICER telescope.
  • The January 23 mission will focus on removing an antenna and testing for microbial life on the ISS exterior.
  • This will be Williams' eighth spacewalk and Hague's fourth.
“On January 16, NASA astronauts Nick Hague and Suni Williams will exit the space station to repair the NICER X-ray telescope.” — International Space Station

These spacewalks are part of NASA's ongoing efforts to maintain and upgrade the International Space Station.

item.title: Planetary Parade: A Celestial Spectacle for Stargazers in India and Odisha - OTV News
item.description:
Planetary Parade: Celestial spectacle for stargazers in India and Odisha

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: OTV News

Astronomy enthusiasts across India are gearing up for a celestial treat with a rare planetary parade visible to the naked eye. This event promises a breathtaking alignment of major planets in the evening sky.

  • The planetary alignment peaks on January 18, featuring Venus and Saturn closely aligned.
  • The event is visible until around 20:30 on that date.
  • Apart from Venus and Saturn, other planets may also be observed throughout the month.
  • The phenomenon encourages public engagement and educational opportunities in astronomy.
  • Optimal viewing conditions are suggested away from urban light pollution.
“Such planetary alignments are infrequent, making them a highly anticipated event for astronomy aficionados.”

This planetary parade offers a unique experience for both amateur astronomers and the general public, fostering interest and education in astronomy.

item.title: World's 1st wooden satellite deploys from ISS to demonstrate cleaner spacecraft tech (photo) - Space.com
item.description:
World's 1st wooden satellite deploys from ISS to demonstrate cleaner spacecraft tech (photo)

Publication Date: January 7, 2024
Source: Space.com

An experimental satellite made of wood has been deployed from the International Space Station (ISS) to test the durability of sustainable materials in space.

  • The satellite, named LignoSat, was developed by Kyoto University and Sumitomo Forestry.
  • It is a 1U cubesat measuring 4 inches (10 cm) on each side and will remain in space for about six months.
  • The project aims to explore the viability of wooden materials as a cleaner alternative to traditional aluminum in satellite construction.
  • During the mission, researchers will monitor the satellite's response to extreme temperatures and radiation.
  • Potential outcomes of success could lead to eco-friendly satellites that do not contribute to environmental pollution upon reentry.
“If we can prove our first wooden satellite works, we want to pitch it to Elon Musk's SpaceX,” said retired Japanese astronaut Takao Doi.

The successful testing of LignoSat may provide valuable insights into the use of renewable materials in aerospace engineering, addressing growing concerns over satellite pollution and environmental impacts.

item.title: Fossil discovery sheds light on the early evolution of animal nervous systems - Phys.org
item.description:
Fossil discovery sheds light on the early evolution of animal nervous systems

Publication Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: Science Advances

An international team of scientists has uncovered insights into the evolutionary development of the ventral nerve cord in ecdysozoan animals, including insects, nematodes, and priapulid worms.

  • The research explores Cambrian fossils to understand the structure and evolution of nervous systems.
  • Fossils include those of early Scalidophora, providing a glimpse into ancient nervous system architecture.
  • Findings suggest that the common ancestor of ecdysozoans likely had a single ventral nerve cord.
  • The study connects nervous system evolution with broader trends in animal segmentation and movement.
“This leads us to propose that the common ancestor of all ecdysozoans possessed a single ventral nerve cord,” said Dr. Chema Martin-Durán.

This research advances our knowledge of ancient animal development and the fossil record's role in understanding evolutionary processes.

item.title: Star escapes ravenous supermassive black hole, leaving behind its stellar partner - Space.com
item.description:
Star Escapes Supermassive Black Hole in Rare Event

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Space.com

Astronomers have observed a supermassive black hole emitting powerful flashes as it potentially captured and partially destroyed a binary star system. This event, known as a Tidal Disruption Event (TDE), is rare with only a handful of occurrences displaying multiple flares.

  • The event, designated ASASSN-22ci, involves a supermassive black hole about 408 million light-years away.
  • Two distinct flares have been observed, occurring 720 days apart.
  • Team leader Jason Hinkle notes that while these events are rare, they provide significant insights into TDE physics.
“The uniformity of the two flares... suggests a single star disrupted two times,” stated Hinkle.

This discovery offers new opportunities for astronomers to study TDEs, possibly aiding in understanding black hole behaviors and dynamics.

item.title: In August 1831, The Sun Appeared Blue – And We Now Know Why - IFLScience
item.description:
The Mystery Behind the Blue Sun of August 1831 Uncovered

Published: 11 hours ago Source: IFLScience

In August 1831, people reported the Sun appearing in strange colors, which led to a two-year period of unusually cool weather globally. Recent research has identified the eruption's source, linking it to the Zavaritskii caldera on Simushir Island in the Kuril Islands.

  • The anomaly was likely caused by volcanic dust scattering sunlight.
  • Temperatures dropped by approximately 1°C (1.8°F) globally.
  • The eruption has been confirmed as highly explosive based on ice-core sample analysis.
  • Collaboration with international colleagues provided critical ash samples for the study.
  • The research highlights volcanoes' potential climatic impacts, which could disrupt global temperatures significantly.
The moment in the lab when we analyzed the two ashes together, one from the volcano and one from the ice core, was a genuine eureka moment. I couldn’t believe the numbers were identical.

This study emphasizes the need for preparedness and response strategies for potential future volcanic eruptions that could mimic the 1831 event.

item.title: Princeton bioengineers shed light on how and when embryonic cells organize themselves - Engineering at Princeton University
item.description:
Princeton Engineering - Princeton bioengineers shed light on how and when embryonic cells organize themselves

Publication Date: October 2, 2023
Source: Nature Cell Biology

Princeton engineers have made a significant breakthrough in understanding how embryonic cells transition from symmetry to asymmetrical structures, unlocking new insights into developmental disorders.

  • Discovery that transformation in cell organization can be predicted earlier than previously thought.
  • The researchers used stem cell models to study chemical signals that dictate embryonic development.
  • Identified early chemical signals that can predict whether cells will become part of the 'head' or 'tail' of an embryo.
  • Observations revealed a mechanism for cell sorting which explains how tail cells gather together.
  • The findings have potential implications for improving our understanding of mammalian development.
  • Future research may utilize these tools for additional developmental processes.
“There is a ton of potential in these stem cell models for both basic science and applications that could improve human health.” - Harry McNamara

Overall, this research opens exciting new avenues for the study of mammalian embryonic development and may enhance the understanding of related disorders.

item.title: Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space - Tech Xplore
item.description:
Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space

Publication Date: January 10, 2025

Source: TechXplore

Radiation testing indicates that organic solar cells may offer significant advantages over traditional silicon and gallium arsenide cells in space applications, according to a study from the University of Michigan.

  • The study investigates the molecular impacts of radiation exposure on organic solar cells.
  • Organic solar cells can be flexible, lightweight, and outperform conventional materials in radiation tests.
  • While small molecule-based organic solar cells resisted proton damage for three years, those made from polymers showed efficiency loss.
  • Protons cleave side chains of polymers, creating electron traps that degrade cell performance.
  • Thermal heating may help repair damage, but questions remain about the feasibility in space environments.
“We might find ways to fill the traps with other atoms, eliminating this problem.” - Stephen Forrest

The research opens up avenues for future study on organic materials in space, highlighting their potential for innovative solar energy solutions.

item.title: New device harnesses microwave flow reaction to convert biomass into useful sugars - Phys.org
item.description:
New Device Converts Biomass into Useful Sugars Using Microwave Technology

Publication Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: Phys.org

Researchers at Kyushu University have developed a device that efficiently converts complex polysaccharides into simple monosaccharides using microwave flow reactions and a solid acid catalyst.

  • Device utilizes continuous-flow hydrolysis to convert cellobiose into glucose.
  • The process involves heating a sulfonated carbon catalyst with microwaves to enhance its activity.
  • Hydrolysis can help in converting biomass into valuable sugars for food and pharmaceuticals.
“Microwaves form a localized high-temperature reaction field on the solid catalyst, which can lead to higher catalytic activity while keeping the overall reaction system at a lower temperature,” explains Tsubaki.

The innovative approach aims to enhance sustainability in chemical processing and improve biomass conversion efficiency.

item.title: Parade of planets: Catch a rare glimpse of seven planets at the same time on THIS date - Mint
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Parade of planets: Catch a rare glimpse of seven planets at the same time on THIS date | Mint - Mint
item.description:
Parade of Planets: A Rare Celestial Event This Month

Date & Source: January 2023, Live Mint

A spectacular astronomical phenomenon known as the “parade of planets” can be spotted in the skies this month, allowing sky gazers to see seven planets (excluding Earth) align across the night sky.

  • Each evening this month, four bright planets will be visible.
  • A close approach of Venus and Saturn is expected on January 17 and 18.
  • Mars will be occulted by the Moon on January 13, visible in the continental US and Eastern Canada.
  • The best view will occur a couple of hours after dark, with planets positioned in various directions.
  • This event is rare, and viewers may need a telescope to fully appreciate it.
“Four or five bright planets at once will be visible along a line in the sky, even though planets always appear along a line.” - NASA

This celestial event provides a unique opportunity for both amateur and seasoned astronomers to witness an alignment that doesn't happen every year.

item.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launching on record-breaking 25th flight today - Space.com
item.description:
SpaceX Falcon 9 Rocket Launches on Record-Breaking 25th Flight

Date: January 10, 2025

Source: Space.com

SpaceX continues to extend its rocket-reuse record with the Falcon 9 rocket.

The Falcon 9 rocket is set to launch from Florida's Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, carrying 21 Starlink broadband satellites, including 13 with direct-to-cell capabilities, at 1:05 p.m. EST today.

  • This mission marks the 25th flight for the rocket's first stage.
  • Thirteen of the previous 24 flights have been dedicated to Starlink missions.
  • SpaceX will provide a live webcast of the launch starting five minutes before liftoff.
  • The first stage is expected to land in the Atlantic Ocean approximately eight minutes after launch.
"Starlink is the largest satellite constellation ever deployed and is growing all the time." - Jonathan McDowell

Today's launch is part of SpaceX's ongoing efforts to revolutionize satellite communication with its expansive Starlink network.

item.title: AI Enhances Northern Lights Classification and Geomagnetic Storm Forecasting - Gadgets 360
item.description:
AI Transforms Auroral Research, Helping Predict Geomagnetic Storms

Publication Date: January 2025, Source: Gadgets 360

A breakthrough in auroral research has been achieved through artificial intelligence, aiding scientists in classifying northern lights and enhancing geomagnetic storm forecasting.

  • Over 700 million auroral images categorized for better analysis.
  • Utilizes NASA's THEMIS dataset, recorded every three seconds from 23 stations.
  • Machine-learning algorithms classify images into six categories: arc, diffuse, discrete, cloudy, moon, and clear/no aurora.
  • The new database is expected to significantly improve future auroral research.
  • Collaboration with researchers from the University of Alaska-Fairbanks and NASA.
“The vast dataset holds crucial information about Earth's protective magnetosphere.” - Jeremiah Johnson

This advancement will not only enhance understanding of solar interactions but also serve as a valuable resource for ongoing studies in space weather.

item.title: Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space - University of Michigan News
item.description:
Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space

Publication Date: Not specified Source: University of Michigan

The University of Michigan’s latest study suggests that organic solar cells, made from carbon-based materials, could outperform traditional silicon and gallium arsenide cells in space. These organic cells show resilience against radiation, making them suitable for space missions.

  • Organic materials demonstrate no degradation after three years of radiation exposure.
  • Silicon semiconductors suffer performance drops due to proton irradiation.
  • Proton radiation can create electron traps that degrade solar cell efficiency.
  • Organic solar cells are lighter and more flexible than their silicon counterparts.
  • Thermal annealing may help repair radiation damage, but further research is needed to understand self-healing in space.
“Silicon semiconductors aren’t stable in space because of proton irradiation coming from the sun.” - Yongxi Li

The findings represent a significant advancement in solar technology for extraterrestrial use, encouraging further exploration into the reliability and application of organic solar cells in future space missions.

item.title: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory back online after 2024 data center flood - Space.com
item.description:
NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory back online after 2024 data center flood

Publication Date: January 8, 2025

Source: Space.com

More than a month after a flooded data center at Stanford University knocked out data processing operations for two NASA sun-studying spacecraft, solar scientists are starting to regain access to information and images beamed to Earth by the instruments.

A restored database server is 'functioning adequately' with back-up servers ready for use, and data processing has begun from the time of the flooding incident going forward.

  • The flooding incident on November 26 damaged roughly 20% of the computer systems.
  • The Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI) and Atmospheric Imaging Array (AIA) archives became inaccessible.
  • The first stage of the processing pipeline for incoming data was restarted by December 20, but with reduced capacity.
  • Despite the outage, the spacecraft continued to operate normally, meaning no science data was lost.
"Restoration of the database servers that manage the storage of the billions of files in the JSOC repository is our first and foremost challenge — this is our highest priority."

The team is awaiting replacement parts for other damaged data servers, which are expected to arrive soon, to assess recoverable data.

item.title: Astronomers have for decades tried to figure out how Pluto captured its largest moon. Now, there’s a new theory - CNN
item.description:
How did Pluto’s large moon Charon form? With a ‘kiss,’ scientists say

Date: Not provided
Source: CNN

For decades, astronomers have tried to determine how Pluto acquired its unusually large moon Charon. New research suggests a “kiss and capture” collision occurred billions of years ago.

  • Charon is about half the size of Pluto.
  • Research indicates that Pluto and Charon likely collided and briefly stuck together before separating.
  • This new behavior contrasts with typical collision scenarios, which are classified as 'hit and run' or 'graze and merge.'
  • The study could provide insight into how planets form and may indicate the presence of a subsurface ocean beneath Pluto's icy crust.
  • Charon and Earth’s moon both represent large fractions of the size of the bodies they orbit.
  • The collision may have occurred around 4 billion years ago, early in the solar system's history.
“What we’ve discovered is something entirely different — a ‘kiss and capture’ scenario where the bodies collide, stick together briefly and then separate while remaining gravitationally bound.” – Adeene Denton

This research challenges previous theories and opens new possibilities for understanding the formation of celestial bodies in the outer solar system.

item.title: NASA astronaut reveals the rules they have to follow if someone dies in space - Daily Express US
item.description:
NASA Astronaut Reveals the Rules They Have to Follow If Someone Dies in Space

Publication Date: January 7, 2025 | Source: Express

A former NASA astronaut, Chris Hadfield, disclosed the protocols in place for dealing with an astronaut's death while in space. NASA prepares its personnel through death simulations that include scenarios like catastrophic events.

  • Hadfield mentioned that if a death occurred during an EVA, the body would be brought inside the airlock.
  • Bodies decompose faster in spacesuits, making storage of the body in a cooler area necessary.
  • NASA’s guidelines specify the options for remains after a death on the ISS include returning the body to Earth or disposal in space.
  • The health and safety of the remaining crew must be prioritized to prevent biohazard risks.
“The goal is to ensure that the procedures are performed as set forth, professionally, and with dignity and respect without compromising the health of the surviving crew.” - Chris Hadfield

In conclusion, Hadfield's insights illuminate the serious considerations NASA must account for in the event of an astronaut's death while maintaining crew safety and dignity.

item.title: See Mars at its best and closest this weekend — no telescope required - Livescience.com
item.description:
See Mars at its best and closest this weekend — no telescope required

Publication Date: January 8, 2023 | Source: Live Science

This month, Mars will shine brighter than it has since December 2022 as it reaches opposition, providing excellent views of the Red Planet until 2027.

  • Mars reaches opposition on January 16, appearing brightest and largest when Earth is positioned directly between Mars and the sun.
  • On January 12, Mars will be at its closest to Earth, at a distance of 59.7 million miles (96.1 million km).
  • Observers should look east at sunset between January 12 and January 16 for the best views.
  • This month’s full moon will briefly block Mars, creating a rare lunar occultation on January 13.
  • Venus will compete in brightness but will set a couple of hours after sunset.
"Mars will appear brighter and larger than at any other time in its 687-Earth-day orbit."

In summary, this weekend is a unique opportunity to observe Mars, especially as it reaches its closest point and brightest visibility.

item.title: World's darkest and clearest skies at risk from industrial megaproject - Phys.org
item.description:
World's Darkest and Clearest Skies Under Threat from Industrial Project

Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: ESO

This article discusses the significant threat posed by a proposed industrial megaproject near the ESO's Paranal Observatory in Chile, which could lead to light pollution and harm astronomical observations.

  • The project, submitted by AES Andes, is planned just 5 to 11 kilometers from the observatory.
  • Paranal Observatory is renowned for its clear skies, crucial for astronomical research.
  • Notable scientific achievements include the first image of an exoplanet and contributions to understanding the universe's expansion.
  • The project would cover over 3000 hectares and poses risks of dust and light pollution.
  • Experts urge the relocation of the project to preserve the unique dark skies essential for astronomy.
"Chile, and in particular Paranal, is a truly special place for astronomy—its dark skies are a natural heritage that transcends its borders and benefits all humanity." - Itziar de Gregorio, ESO's Representative in Chile

The potential industrial development endangers not just local astronomy but the global scientific community’s ability to observe the universe effectively, urging the need for responsible site selection to protect this vital resource.
